Anansi, the crows, 
 and the crocodiles 
 
 Ghanaian folktale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day there was a great famine in the
 land. No one had anything to eat except
 
 the crows. 
 
 
 Each morning they flew a long distance
 to where there was a tre with ripe figs in
 the midle of a wide river. Then they flew
 
 back with the figs for themselves and
 their relatives. 
 
 
 The sight of so many figs made Anansi's
 mouth water. How could he get them for
 
 himself? 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He thought of a plan. 
 He carefuly covered his botom with 
 
 sticky beswax. Then he tok a piece of 
 clay pot and went to se the crows. 
 
 
 “Please could you help me?” he asked. “I 
 ned a live coal to get my fire going 
 
 again.” 
 As they were geting the coal from the 
 
 fire, Anansi carefuly sat firmly on one of 
 the largest figs, so that it would stick to 
 his botom. He thanked the crows, and 
 
 huried home to enjoy the fig. 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 But one fig wasn’t enough for him. He
 
 went back a second time, and did the
 same. When he went back a third time,
 
 the crows began to get suspicious.
 
 “Why do you kep coming back to us to
 
 get a coal?” they said. Anansi answered,
 “Every time when I get home, the coal
 has burnt out.” 
 
 
 “You’re lying!” said the crows. “You just
 
 want our fod!” 
 “That’s not true,” said Anansi. 
 And he started crying. 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The crows felt sory for him. The next 
 morning at first light, each crow gave him 
 
 a feather. He flew with them to the fig 
 tre in the midle of the wide river. When 
 he saw the luscious figs, Anansi wanted 
 
 them al for himself. 
 
 Each time a crow tried to pick a fig, he 
 
 shouted out, “That one is mine! I saw it 
 first!” And then he tok the fig and put it 
 
 into his bag. Eventualy he had al the figs 
 and the crows had none. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He was left al alone as the darknes
 began to fal. 
 
 
 “If I don’t want to stay in this tre for the
 rest of my life,” he said to himself, “I’l
 
 just have to jump into the air like the
 crows”. 
 
 
 So he tok a dep breath, jumped,
 and…PLOP! 
 
 He fel into the river right among the
 crocodiles. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “What do we have here?” said a gruf 
 crocodile voice. “A tasty morsel to eat, 
 
 nyum…” 
 “Oh please don’t,” said Anansi. And he 
 began to cry. “I’m one of you, don’t you 
 
 know? I got lost in the days of your 
 grandfathers and no one was able to find 
 me. You’re the first of my relatives I’ve 
 
 ever met!” 
 
 
 He cried so much that the crocodiles felt 
 sory for him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The oldest crocodile said, “We’l know
 you’re one of us if you can eat and enjoy
 
 mud soup just like we do.” 
 They gave him a pot of dirty brown water.
 “Just like my grandmother used to make
 
 it!” Anansi said. 
 
 But he made a hole in the ground with his
 
 back fot, and a hole in the pot with his
 front fot. As he pretended to drink the
 
 soup, it ozed down through the pot into
 the hole beneath his fet. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Delicious!” he exclaimed, giving back the 
 
 empty pot. 
 
 
 “Now we know you are definitely one of 
 us,” the crocodiles said. 
 So they alowed Anansi to slep in their 
 
 hole with them for the night. 
 
 
 “Tomorow morning I’l tel you the story 
 of my life,” said Anansi as they fel 
 aslep. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Early the next morning, before first light,
 
 Anansi woke up one of the crocodiles.
 “I want to go and fetch my wife and
 children from acros the river, so that
 
 they can help me tel my story. Wil you
 help me before the others wake up?” he
 
 asked the crocodile. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The crocodile was grumpy at being 
 
 woken up so early. 
 “Please help me! You swim much faster 
 than I do,” Anansi said. 
 
 The crocodile agred, and Anansi rode 
 on his back to the bank of the river. 
 
 
 He climbed of quickly. “I’l be back son! 
 Don’t go away!” Anansi said, as he 
 
 disapeared through the gras. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As far as we know, the crocodile is
 
 waiting for him stil, with just his long
 snout and his beady eyes above the
 surface of the river.
